Award.AwardTitle: Organometallic Chemistry of Periodic pi-Electron Surfaces: Carbon Nanotubes and Graphene
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
This project, supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry Program, involves preparation of a new class of graphitic materials in which the surfaces are functionalized with transition metals, thereby allowing the formation of atomic scale interconnects that consist of bis-hexahapto-metal-bonds between the benzenoid ring systems; this approach is anticipated to provide a method to increase the dimensionality of the electronic structure of the 1-D carbon nanotubes and the 2-D graphene sheets. Preliminary experiments show that chromium complexes are accessible by a wide range of preparative methods, which include solution phase functionalization with chromium carbonyl precursors, solid state thermal reactions under pressure beginning with mono-hexahapto complexes and gas phase metal vapor synthesis using electron beam physical vapor deposition (e-beam). All of these materials show evidence of a change in the electrical conductivities of the starting graphitic structures on organometallic functionalization and it is the purpose of this proposal to broaden the fundamental understanding of the interaction between metals and graphene surfaces and to refine the synthesis and physical characterization of the materials. Based on a frontier molecular orbital analysis of the electronic structure of graphene at the Dirac point, graphene is identified as an excellent ligand in coordination complexes and it is apparent that a wide variety of organometallic intercalation compounds can be prepared. Thus the goal of the proposed research is to develop a class of novel transition metal-graphene materials that exhibit unique electronic properties and to lay the foundation for electronic interconnects between graphitic surfaces at the atomic level. The new materials may be of interest as the active constituent in electronic, opto-electronic and spintronic devices.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
This project will lead to a new class of carbon nanotube and graphene frameworks that are held together by covalent, rather than ionic bonding. The proposed materials are expected to have novel catalytic, electronic and magnetic properties; a number of the known charge transfer graphite compounds exhibit superconductivity and such a possibility exists with the proposed organometallic compounds. The broader impact of this project will be most evident in the participation and training of students at the undergraduate and graduate level which will occur in a highly integrated, multidisciplinary program whose work is directed toward advancements in fundamental and technologically significant aspects of the chemical sciences. The students will be exposed to an extensive suite of modern research tools and will become familiar with the Center for Nanoscale Science and Engineering nanofabrication tools and analytical techniques. We have found that such training serves as an invaluable asset for students that are seeking entry into the electronics industry. Special effort will be devoted to attracting women and minorities into the research program through the California Alliance for Minority Participation (CAMP), the Summer Bridge Research Program and CNAS Dean Summer Internships. This project is supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry Program.

Institution.Name: University of California-Riverside
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA AT RIVERSIDE

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to use organometallic bis-hexahapto (η6) bonds as the electronic interconnects between the surfaces of the periodic π-electron systems present in carbon nanotubes and graphene. The coordination of transition metals to graphitic surfaces led to the first descriptions of metals attached to trivalent carbon atoms of the conjugated carbon allotropes, carbon nanotubes and graphene, by means of covalent bonding that enhances the conductivity. Prior to this work, the covalent functionalization of graphene and carbon nanotubes has led to a decrease in the conductivity and carrier mobility. The main achievements of the project are: 

1. Percolation Studies of Single-Walled Carbon Nanotube (SWCNT) Thin Films.  SWCNT networks offer a unique platform to study the effect of the hexahapto bond on the establishment of electrical contact between graphitic surfaces.  Because the percolation in these films is dominated by the nature of the inter-nanotube contacts, the transport in SWCNT films is sensitive to the formation of interconnects particularly in the vicinity of the percolation threshold where the conducting pathways become severely limited by the low nanotube density (Fig.1). Transition metals from Group 6 and the first row were deposited on SWCNT films by e-beam deposition.

     To benchmark the use of metal interconnects to improve the conductivity of SWCNTs, we studied SWCNT films during deposition of Li, a classic dopant that increases conductivity, and gold, a metal that cannot form η6-bonds with SWCNT. It was found that Cr atoms are more efficient in increasing the film conductivity than doping with Li at the initial stage of metal deposition (less than 0.5 monolayer of metal). Adding Cr atoms to SWCNT thin films results in conductivity enhancement by a factor of 700,000  (Fig. 2).

     The studies on deposition of transition metals on SWCNT networks found that chromium gives rise to the highest conductivities of the transition metals studied to date M(η  6-SWCNT)2 (M = Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Mo, W).  Furthermore, both semiconducting and metallic SWCNT films have similar response to ionic doping and covalent bond formation.

2. Effect of Lanthanide Deposition on Thin Films of SWCNTs.  The deposition of lanthanide metals by e-beam evaporation revealed two different trends in the conductivity (σ) enhancement of SWCNT films (Fig. 3): (i) enhancement less than Cr for Ln = La, Nd, Gd, Dy, Ho, and (ii) enhancement that exceeded or matched the Cr values for Ln = Sm, Eu, Yb. This behavior is related to the accessibility of the 4fm5d1 6s2 electronic configuration for the individual lanthanide atoms. Sm, Eu and Yb not only engage in bis-hexahapto-bonding, but also transfer charge into the conduction band of the SWCNTs and enhance the conductivity of the SWCNT films. These lanthanides form mixed covalent -ionic bonds [(η6-SWCNT)M(η6-SWCNT), where M = Sm, Eu, Yb], which were supported by spectroscopic studies. Near-infrared (NIR) and Raman spectroscopy were used to measure the charge density distributions in (η6-SWCNT)M(η6-SWCNT). The observed suppression of the NIR transitions and the Raman shifts were correlated to the conductivity changes in the films.

3. Photochemical Generation of Bis-hexahapto Chromium Interconnects between the Graphene Surfaces of Single-Walled Carbon Nanotubes and Graphene Nanoplatelets. In addition to the e-beam deposition, the reactions of Cr(CO)6, Cr(η 6-benzene)(CO)3, and Cr(η6-benzene)2 under photochemical condition result in the functionalization of SWCNTs and graphene. This is a facile route for ambient temperature formation of organometallic interconnects between the graphene surfaces of SWCNTs, and is a key step forward to eliminate the need for high vacuum reaction vessels.  

Intellectual Merit of Previous Work  This project led to synthetic routes that electrically interconnect trivalent carbon atoms of the conjugated carbon allotropes - carbon nanotubes and graphene -  by forming η6-coordination modes to their π-systems. This preserves the delocalization and conductivity within the extended p-subunits, and offers a seamless electronic interconnection between the conjugated fragments. Another key outcome is the formation of mixed covalent - ionic bis-hexahapto bond in compounds formed on interaction of the lanthanide metals M = Sm, Eu with carbon nanotubes.

Broader Impacts. The results from the project were presented at 13 national and international meetings. The research was summarized in 15 papers published in peer reviewed journals (deposited NSF-PAR), two book chapters, and one manuscript in preparation. Students supported by this award received PhD degrees in Chemistry (two students) and PhD degrees in Chemical Engineering (2 students). The multi-disciplinary training received by the students was critical in their career growth. Two of the students and one associated researcher were hired in the semiconductor industry, one student and one post-doctoral scholar pursued academic careers.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The goal of this project is to use organometallic bis-hexahapto (η6) bonds as the electronic interconnects between the surfaces of the periodic π-electron systems present in carbon nanotubes and graphene. The coordination of transition metals to graphitic surfaces led to the first descriptions of metals attached to trivalent carbon atoms of the conjugated carbon allotropes, carbon nanotubes and graphene, by means of covalent bonding that enhances the conductivity. Prior to this work, the covalent functionalization of graphene and carbon nanotubes has led to a decrease in the conductivity and carrier mobility. The main achievements of the project are: 1. Percolation Studies of Single-Walled Carbon Nanotube (SWCNT) Thin Films. SWCNT networks offer a unique platform to study the effect of the hexahapto bond on the establishment of electrical contact between graphitic surfaces. Because the percolation in these films is dominated by the nature of the inter-nanotube contacts, the transport in SWCNT films is sensitive to the formation of interconnects particularly in the vicinity of the percolation threshold where the conducting pathways become severely limited by the low nanotube density (Fig.1). Transition metals from Group 6 and the first row were deposited on SWCNT films by e-beam deposition. To benchmark the use of metal interconnects to improve the conductivity of SWCNTs, we studied SWCNT films during deposition of Li, a classic dopant that increases conductivity, and gold, a metal that cannot form η6-bonds with SWCNT. It was found that Cr atoms are more efficient in increasing the film conductivity than doping with Li at the initial stage of metal deposition (less than 0.5 monolayer of metal). Adding Cr atoms to SWCNT thin films results in conductivity enhancement by a factor of 700,000 (Fig. 2). The studies on deposition of transition metals on SWCNT networks found that chromium gives rise to the highest conductivities of the transition metals studied to date M(η 6-SWCNT)2 (M = Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Mo, W). Furthermore, both semiconducting and metallic SWCNT films have similar response to ionic doping and covalent bond formation. 2. Effect of Lanthanide Deposition on Thin Films of SWCNTs. The deposition of lanthanide metals by e-beam evaporation revealed two different trends in the conductivity (σ) enhancement of SWCNT films (Fig. 3): (i) enhancement less than Cr for Ln = La, Nd, Gd, Dy, Ho, and (ii) enhancement that exceeded or matched the Cr values for Ln = Sm, Eu, Yb. This behavior is related to the accessibility of the 4fm5d1 6s2 electronic configuration for the individual lanthanide atoms. Sm, Eu and Yb not only engage in bis-hexahapto-bonding, but also transfer charge into the conduction band of the SWCNTs and enhance the conductivity of the SWCNT films. These lanthanides form mixed covalent -ionic bonds [(η6-SWCNT)M(η6-SWCNT), where M = Sm, Eu, Yb], which were supported by spectroscopic studies. Near-infrared (NIR) and Raman spectroscopy were used to measure the charge density distributions in (η6-SWCNT)M(η6-SWCNT). The observed suppression of the NIR transitions and the Raman shifts were correlated to the conductivity changes in the films. 3. Photochemical Generation of Bis-hexahapto Chromium Interconnects between the Graphene Surfaces of Single-Walled Carbon Nanotubes and Graphene Nanoplatelets. In addition to the e-beam deposition, the reactions of Cr(CO)6, Cr(η 6-benzene)(CO)3, and Cr(η6-benzene)2 under photochemical condition result in the functionalization of SWCNTs and graphene. This is a facile route for ambient temperature formation of organometallic interconnects between the graphene surfaces of SWCNTs, and is a key step forward to eliminate the need for high vacuum reaction vessels. Intellectual Merit of Previous Work This project led to synthetic routes that electrically interconnect trivalent carbon atoms of the conjugated carbon allotropes - carbon nanotubes and graphene - by forming η6-coordination modes to their π-systems. This preserves the delocalization and conductivity within the extended p-subunits, and offers a seamless electronic interconnection between the conjugated fragments. Another key outcome is the formation of mixed covalent - ionic bis-hexahapto bond in compounds formed on interaction of the lanthanide metals M = Sm, Eu with carbon nanotubes. Broader Impacts. The results from the project were presented at 13 national and international meetings. The research was summarized in 15 papers published in peer reviewed journals (deposited NSF-PAR), two book chapters, and one manuscript in preparation. Students supported by this award received PhD degrees in Chemistry (two students) and PhD degrees in Chemical Engineering (2 students). The multi-disciplinary training received by the students was critical in their career growth. Two of the students and one associated researcher were hired in the semiconductor industry, one student and one post-doctoral scholar pursued academic careers.
